audio_caption: The audio clip begins with instrumental music in a light, upbeat style.  The music transitions to a single male speaker introducing Scratch as a programming language. He speaks in a clear and informative tone, explaining what Scratch is and who it is designed for, characterizing it as easy to use, visual, colorful, and fun. The clip ends with a short vocalization.

The audio features a single male speaker inquiring, "So where do you get Scratch?" In response, another male speaker, providing information, states Scratch is available from the MIT Media Lab and developed by a group called the Lifelong Kindergarten group. The speaker then provides the website address for Scratch, mentioning its availability on Windows, Apple, and Linux operating systems.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker who explains how to download Scratch. He speaks in an informative tone, telling the listener to "open your browser and point it to scratch.mit.edu" and then "click the download Scratch button." He further explains that there is a form that you should fill out, instructing listeners that if they're under 13 to not fill out the email address information. The speaker then directs to "click 'continue with Scratch download'". He describes that this step leads to a new screen with the choices of operating systems. The speaker instructs to "click on the program to download it to your computer."

The clip begins with a male speaker providing instructions on how to start Scratch, mentioning to "double clicking the desktop icon" or the "program from your start menu" and then transitioning to a statement "so let's get started."

The audio begins with a male speaker introducing the Scratch interface, mentioning the character known as a "sprite" or "actor" on a "stage" and the script writing area. He describes the different function categories available on the left for controlling the actor's movements, appearance, sounds, and behavior. The speaker mentions more advanced capabilities will be discussed later, then decides to demonstrate a simple action.

A single male speaker explains how to make an actor move on the stage by dragging functions to the script, specifically, the "move ten steps" function. He modifies this function to move "one hundred steps". He emphasizes the ability to test changes without damaging anything. Then, he instructs the listener to click to run the program to make the actor move. He notes that the actor moved off the stage and so the speaker drags it back on. Finally, the speaker adjusts the program to make the actor turn ninety degrees each time it moves one hundred steps.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing how to move a figure and turn it 90 degrees by dragging blocks together. The speaker's tone is instructional and matter-of-fact. The speaker then says he'll control how the figure does that. The audio shifts to a discussion of control features and repeat blocks.

The clip features a male speaker explaining the function of a "repeat" command in a program. He explains how he wants to use it to move and turn four times.  He then explains that there's a space where you can put your existing program by dragging and dropping. He demonstrates by dragging and dropping it in, noting the automatic control box surrounding the function he created. He has the listener watch the function, and then says that it looked fast and that was probably too fast. He decides to make a modification to his program, by clicking and dragging it out of there and putting in another function. He then wants the program to move 100 steps and wait for one second. He then grabs the entire block, put it back into repeat and has the listener watch. He adds that he'll put a little wait in there so you can see what's going on. He adds to make things a little more interesting, that he will add a pen. He says he is going to say pen down.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing what will happen when he runs a program, stating it will create a little box. He suggests that while "playing around" he might mess things up, but he can create a function to make things nice and neat. He mentions clearing the screen and adding complexity later. The speaker then says he wants to make something more complex.

The audio clip features a single male speaker explaining a program or process. He speaks in an instructional tone, mentioning "moving 100 steps," taking out a "program," removing a "weight function," and deleting something by right-clicking. He describes turning "90 degrees" and then doing something "a little bit different" with "105 degrees." The speaker suggests repeating this five times and comments on the outcome, noting that the subject "turned off in a strange direction."

A male speaker is explaining a visual pattern and its behavior when cleared, noting its "geometric pattern." He speaks in an informative tone, then transitions to discussing how to fix the pattern, speaking about specific locations and directions on the stage, referencing coordinates like "0,0." Throughout his speech, the mouse clicks.

The audio clip starts with a single male speaker explaining that he wants his actor to return to location zero-zero. He observes a line and says, "Oops, I've got a little line here," suggesting he probably wanted to clear something after doing that. He continues by stating that he wants the actor to point in the direction of ninety degrees, followed by "So let's see what happens when I run that," and then comments that the actor is back to normal. He mentions that he can run his function as many times as he wants and the actor will always return home. The speaker then adds that he can also clean up his script by right-clicking and using the clean-up function to make everything nice and pretty. Finally, he describes the actor or sprite, suggesting this is about a programmed environment.
The clip begins with a male speaker describing the features of a stage, including actors and the stage itself. He suggests changing the background to make it less boring than a "plain white field".

The audio clip begins with one male speaker explaining how to add a background, indicating they've just clicked on "stage" and can write a script for it. He transitions to discussing backgrounds, stating that he's going to import a picture from those available inside Scratch, and then picks something from "nature", specifically a "desert scene". He returns to talking about his sprite, and then script. The audio ends with him running a little function and discussing cleaning up afterward.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing how to change the sprite or add a new one. He mentions deleting an actor and its associated script, then selecting a new sprite from a file, referencing an example of picking a buffalo. After, he suggests picking something new, painting a sprite, or importing one from the user's system. The speaker's tone is instructional.

The audio features a male speaker who begins by emphasizing that Scratch has a large number of sprites as part of its system. He then concludes with a quick and dirty introduction to the Scratch development system. This speech is followed by a low-frequency hum or drone sound.
